media:content.media:description: SACRAMENTO,CA-Alicia Cruz. center, of El Grove, California takes part in a protest really at the California State Capitol. She said she was there to protect civil liberties, the future for her children, and future livelihoods. CHP officers wearing riot gear were brought in to use the protesters off of the capitol grounds during a protest rally held on Friday, May 1, 2020. Over 1,500 people attending a rally at the capitol in Sacramento asking for the civil liberties and the opening of the economy, closed due to the coronavirus. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- FRIDAY, MAY 1, 2020: Gareth Davies, of Aliso Viejo, parades the American flag while defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's "hard close' of OC beaches as he walks across a mostly empty beach where surfers were also defying the order before joining thousands of protesters rallying at the ``March to Open California'' which called on Gov. Newsom and city officials to relax the state's stay-at-home orders under COVID-19 in Huntington Beach, CA, on May 1, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: On GoFundMe in the time of coronavirus: pleas in the dark for money for food and rent
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: In the coronavirus shutdown, people turn to GoFundMe to ask strangers for the basics: money for food and rent to survive
item.content:encoded: In the coronavirus shutdown, people turn to GoFundMe to ask strangers for the basics: money for food and rent to survive

media:content.media:description: ALHAMBRA, CA-MAY 1, 2020: Roberta Wall, 63, a singing waitress at Micelli's Italian restaurant on Cahuenga Blvd in Universal City, is photographed at her home in Alhambra. Wall, who has worked there since 1986 has been out of work since March 15, when the restaurant stopped having dine in customers due to the coronavirus outbreak. She posted a GoFundMe asking for help but didn't tell anyone she knew because she figured they needed help as much as she did so she got no donations. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fear, uncertainty, exhaustion: One doctor's shift in the UCLA emergency room
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: An ER doctor promises a COVID-19 patient tests, a bed, oxygen and wishes she could do more.
item.content:encoded: An ER doctor promises a COVID-19 patient tests, a bed, oxygen and wishes she could do more.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - APRIL 06: Dr. Lisa Dabby, 41, an emergency room physician with UCLA Medical Center in Santa Monica is assisted by Sr. emergency trauma technician Jorge Velasco in the donning of a PAPR (powered air-purifying respirator) in the emergency room where they are on the front line of the coronavirus COVID-19 outbreak. During a typical 10-hour shift, she treats appendicitis, overdoses, skateboard accidents, arrhythmia, the usual off-the-street accidents, illnesses and conditions that flare up without notice. With more than 10 years at the hospital, she knows what to expect and how to treat it, but the coronavirus has changed that. She treats about 20 patients a day who arrive with coughs, fevers, shortness of breath and the fear and uncertainty that this pandemic has brought.UCLA Medical Center, Santa Monica on Monday, April 6, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. UCLA Medical Center, Santa Monica on Monday, April 6, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Will Orange County enforce Newsom beach closure? Officials vow a fight
item.dc:creator: Anh Do, Hannah Fry, Richard Winton
item.description: Huntington Beach and Dana Point have voted to seek injunctions, and the Orange County sheriff has said he doesn't plan to arrest beachgoers.
item.content:encoded: Huntington Beach and Dana Point have voted to seek injunctions, and the Orange County sheriff has said he doesn't plan to arrest beachgoers.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 2020: Kids do flips off the lifeguard tower while others relax on the sand on the last day of open beaches in Huntington Beach after Gov. Newsom announced the "hard close" of all Orange County state and local beaches Thursday, April 30, 2020. Newsom's retaliation came after thousands of Californians flocked to the shoreline there over the weekend in defiance of a statewide stay-at-home order enacted to stem the spread of the coronavirus. "When you contact the police chiefs to enforce your will as a leader-in my book you establish a police state" said Huntington Beach resident Pete Hamborg. "It's a moment that Gavin Newsom is taking away from us and are the very moments that empower us to deal with this crisis on a day-to-day basis." "I think the beach, which belongs to all Californians, is critical to our emotional health and well-being." (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: California's indigenous Mexicans and Guatemalans miss vital pandemic information due to language barriers
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Activists who speak indigenous languages reach out to keep Mexican and Central American indigenous communities informed on the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Activists who speak indigenous languages reach out to keep Mexican and Central American indigenous communities informed on the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 17, 2020 - Janet Martinez, left, with the Binational Front of Indigenous Organizations (FIOB), talks with Luis Gabriel, from Oaxaca, Mexico, after giving him a relief check in Los Angeles on April 17, 2020. Gabriel is one of many indigenous people from Mexico and Guatemala who have lost employment due to the coronavirus. The Binational Front of Indigenous Organizations was given a $10,000 grant and an additional $5,000 donation to help indigenous people from Mexico and Guatemala, who are out of work in Los Angeles. Workers with the FIOB have been helping those who have lost their jobs by providing some funding and producing educational videos in indigenous languages. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, April 14, 2020, file photo California Gov. Gavin Newsom speaks during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. A coalition of marijuana companies, churches and advocacy groups is asking Newsom for a temporary cut in the state's hefty pot taxes. The group that includes the California State Conference of the NAACP, Los Angeles Metropolitan Churches and the industry group Southern California Coalition warned in a letter to the governor that the coronavirus crisis and a crashing economy will take an especially heavy toll on businesses run by minorities who were disproportionately targeted during the decades-long drug war. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

item.title: Huntington Beach mounts legal fight against Newsom closure of O.C. beaches
item.dc:creator: Anh Do, Richard Winton
item.description: The Huntington Beach City Council voted Thursday night during an emergency session to seek an injunction against Gov. Gavin Newsom's order to close Orange County beaches.
item.content:encoded: The Huntington Beach City Council voted Thursday night during an emergency session to seek an injunction against Gov. Gavin Newsom's order to close Orange County beaches.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 2020: Steve Christopher, right, reads a book in the shade of the pier as a beach-goer does flips across the beach on the last day of open beaches in Huntington Beach after Gov. Newsom announced the "hard close" of all Orange County state and local beaches Thursday, April 30, 2020. "I think it's what needs to be done," Christopher said. "I saw it last week and it was packed." Newsom's retaliation came after thousands of Californians flocked to the shoreline there over the weekend in defiance of a statewide stay-at-home order enacted to stem the spread of the coronavirus. "When you contact the police chiefs to enforce your will as a leader-in my book you establish a police state" said Huntington Beach resident Pete Hamborg. "It's a moment that Gavin Newsom is taking away from us and are the very moments that empower us to deal with this crisis on a day-to-day basis." "I think the beach, which belongs to all Californians, is critical to our emotional health and well-being." (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO CA. APRIL 29, 2020 -- Exterior view of the Federal Correctional Institution Terminal Island in San Pedro. Nearly half of the inmates at the federal prison at Terminal Island in San Pedro have tested positive for the coronavirus in what had has become the nation's worst outbreak in a federal penitentiary. As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the virus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have already died of complications related to COVID-19, according to the Bureau of Prisons. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 24: Jay and Kate Larsen with their two children Reid, 6, and River, 4, started posting a hand-painted riddle on the front lawn each day to brighten up the lives of Mar Vista neighbors after the coronavirus lockdown started. It has become a phenom in the neighborhood, with others using their front yards for riddles, games, and whimsical displays. The Larsons then helped organize a treasure hunt for kids and families creating closer neighborhood bonds, even at a safe distance. Mar VIsta on Friday, April 24, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: The California Highway Patrol says someone who tossed hundreds of medical masks onto a freeway sparked a mini-traffic jam in Union City.
item.content:encoded: The California Highway Patrol says someone who tossed hundreds of medical masks onto a freeway sparked a mini-traffic jam in Union City.

media:content.media:description: One of the spilled masks is visible on the shoulder of southbound Interstate 880 in Union City, Calif., Wednesday, April 29, 2020. In the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, the freeway suffered a mini-traffic jam when someone tossed hundreds of face masks onto the road and some motorists stopped to grab them, the California Highway Patrol reported. At around 1:30 p.m., CHP officers received a report that a white truck had stopped on Interstate 880 in Union City and someone tossed out boxes of medical masks, the CHP reported. (Dai Sugano/Bay Area News Group via AP)

item.title: Gov. Gavin Newsom says staying home now will help reopen California sooner
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom urged Californians to stay home to avoid undoing the progress the state has made in fighting the spread of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom urged Californians to stay home to avoid undoing the progress the state has made in fighting the spread of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, April 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. On a near daily basis since outlining his criteria for someday easing stay-at-home orders, Newsom, who recently allowed scheduled surgeries to resume, has warned Californians that, while he understands their desires to get back to work and a sense of normalcy, lifting the orders too soon could be a public health mistake. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

media:content.media:description: CARSON, CA - APRIL 28, 2020 - - California Assemblyman Mike A. Gipson, of the Sixty-Fourth District, does self-testing at a new drive-up testing site for COVID-19 outside the East Wing of the Congresswoman Juanita Millender-McDonald Community Center in Carson on April 28, 2020. Free COVID-19 testing is available to all city residents thanks to a partnership between the city and US Health Fairs. Carson is the first Southern California city to offer free testing to all its residents. Mayor Albert Robles and members of the Carson City Council also did self-testing at the opening of the new test site. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Terminal Island prison inmates have worst coronavirus outbreak in federal system
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the coronavirus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have died from COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the coronavirus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have died from COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO CA. APRIL 29, 2020 -- Exterior view of the Federal Correctional Institution Terminal Island in San Pedro. Nearly half of the inmates at the federal prison at Terminal Island in San Pedro have tested positive for the coronavirus in what had has become the nation's worst outbreak in a federal penitentiary. As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the virus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have already died of complications related to COVID-19, according to the Bureau of Prisons. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)
